article:
'Sir Roderick (Wallis) Parkes', KCMG, OBE, (2 April 1909 – 2 November
1972) was a British diplomat and colonial administrator. Townend, Peter, ed.
(1970), Burkeâs Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage (105th ed.); The Times, 6 and
7 November 1972

After entering the Indian Civil Service in 1932, he served in the Punjab until
1935. From 1935 to 1947 he was in the Indian Political Service, serving as
Secretary and later Counsellor at the British Legation, Kabul (1936â39) and on
attachment as Liaison Commissioner (States) at the Food Department of the
Government of India (1946â47), in charge of food arrangements for the then
Indian States (population 100 million). He entered the Foreign Service in 1948,
serving as Counsellor (Information) at Cairo (1949â52), Head of Information
Division at Beirut (1952â53), Head of Information Services Department, Foreign
Office (1953â54), and Counsellor and ChargÃ© d'Affaires at Djakarta (1954â55)
during which tour he reported on the first Afro-Asian Conference in Bandung.

He served as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia (1955â56) until diplomatic relations
were severed as a result of the Suez crisis, to Vietnam (1957â60) where he
exercised influence with President Diem at the start of the Communist
insurgency, Busch, Peter (2001) "Supporting the War: Britain's Decision to
send the Thompson Mission to Vietnam, 1960-61", in: Cold War History 2,1 pp.69-
94; McAllister, James and Ian Schulte (2006) "The Limits of Influence in
Vietnam: Britain, the United States and the Diem Regime, 1959-63", in: Small
Wars and Insurgencies 17,1 pp.22-43 and to Sudan (1960â61) - an
appointment cut short by illness. The Times 23 September 1961 In 1962
he was seconded to the Civil Service Commission as Group Chairman, Civil Service
Selection Board, and he served as Ambassador to Jordan from 1962 to 1966.
Following his retirement in 1966, he lived in Castletown, Isle of Man, close to
his friend and former senior colleague, Sir Ralph Stevenson.

The only child of Llywelyn Childs Parkes, registrar to a joint stock company
(and nephew of the inventor Alexander Parkes), and his wife Sara May nÃ©e Green,
Parkes was educated at St Paulâs School and Magdalen College, Oxford. He married
in 1939 Eileen Mary Ernestine (4 May 1915 â 21 July 1977) daughter of Captain
Neville Gardner, and half-sister of the mathematician R.E.A.C. Paley. The
Times, 3 July 1939 and 2 August 1977 They had two sons. His grandson, also
called Roderick Parkes, is a director at the German Institute for International
and Security Affairs. SWP erÃ¶ffnet BÃ¼ro in BrÃ¼ssel,[http://www.thinktankdirectory.org/blog/2009/05/10/swp-eroffnet-buro-
in-brussel/ Think Tank Directory], May 10, 2009
